with a picturesque and vibrant downtown, consisting of numerous art galleries, restaurants and quirky shops sprinkled among coffee shops and performing arts venues. It is home to prestigious Smith College and the Clarke School for the Deaf. Northampton lies only 15 miles north of the City of

Northampton is nationally known for being a bohemian college town and LGBT mecca. It is home to Smith College, a prestigious women's college. This small city of 30,000 is populated, mostly, by artists, intellectuals, political activists, hipsters, and a large LGBT community. Since abnormal is normal in Northampton, it is regarded as one of the most accepting places in the United States.

Long-time residents nickname Northampton "Hamp", while newer residents tend to call it "NoHo". Another nickname for Northampton is the "Paradise City", after Opera singer Jenny Lind remarked that Northampton was "The Paradise of America."

Northampton celebrated its 350th anniversary in 2004. The Town of Northampton (originally named Nonotuck) was granted its Charter in 1654; the City of Northampton was incorporated in 1884.

Liberal politics are an important part of Northampton's scene.  It is with good reason that Northampton was named the "Most liberal medium-size city in the country".

From the east: Take the Massachusetts Turnpike (Interstate 90) to exit 4, and get on Route 91 North. Take exit 18 and turn left.

From the south: Take Interstate 91 North to exit 18. Turn left at the light.

From the west: Take the Massachusetts Turnpike east to exit 4. At exit 4, get on Interstate 91 North, to exit 18. Turn left off the exit. 

You can also take Route 9 east, or Route 2 east to I-91 South, exit 20.

From the north: Take Interstate 91 South, exit 20.
to Northampton. All Busses run through

first.  

Pioneer Valley Transit Authority, or PVTA,
, provides local bus service throughout the Pioneer Valley, from Northampton and Amherst south to the City of Springfield.
Amtrak trains run up and down the Eastern Seaboard to Springfield. You can take a bus or cab from the train station to Northampton (20-25 min).

is 25 miles from Northampton with easy access onto I-91 North.

Boston Logan International Airport in

is 90 miles from Northampton, and can be reached by taking the Mass Turnpike.

TF Greene International Airport in
is 92 miles from Northampton, and can be reached by taking the Mass Turnpike.

, Northampton is eminently walkable, but is also a very bicycle- and pedestrian-friendly city. One can also take a PVTA bus around town and to other cities (e.g. Springfield) and towns in the Pioneer Valley (e.g. Amherst.)

building in Easthampton, 10 minutes outside of Northampton. Peanut Gallery

, Main Street, This gallery has a lovely permanent collection which includes a Dr. Seuss exhibit (great for kids and adults) with many original sketches and paintings, works by John Lennon, Leonard Nimoy, and others.

comes to Smith College and puts on a season of plays.  Excellent performances!  They also have children's theater
content=Has musical acts nightly, usually focusing on lesser-known artists. It is also has a restaurant with a full menu and full bar.
content=Northwest of downtown Northampton. 591 acre conservation area owned by the City of Northampton and co-managed by the Northampton Conservation Commission and Broad Brook Coalition.
, 2.7 mile long linear park from Stoddard St/back of the Stop and Shop on King Street to Look Park/Bridge Rd/JFK school,

, Pleasant St off Main Street. This is a very small, independent theater with two screens.  It shows independent films and foreign films.

, Noho's outdoor theater and concert hall.
On Route 9.  Driving range, also serves burgers, fries, ice cream, etc.  Has clam bakes weekly.
On Main St. in Florence.  Adorable little salon and spa, relaxing getaway for a massage.
content=Classic nineteenth century theater located in the heart of Northampton, showcasing local acts in the performing arts, including music, dance and theater.
content=Local airport that hosts a number of flying programs, including summer camps, pilot training, and air sight-seeing tours.
by the Forbes Library features a roof-top hot tub tht is open year-round.
content=An old department store that was converted into several unique boutique stores and restaurants.
content=The largest selection of natural fiber clothing and accessories in the country. Ask about the endless benefits of hemp and you'll be blown away.
content=This store has clothes and apartment or dorm housewares, but is most noted for its large bizarre toy section and huge selection of cards you would never find at Hallmark.
content=One of the largest and most remarkable yarn stores in the country, noted for its size and its diversity of offerings for spinning, weaving, knitting, and crocheting.
, Main St. Noho's favorite candy shop.  All sorts of candies and chocolates, pay by weight.
, Main St. Great for outdoorsy apparel and shoes.
, Right off Main St, best used bookshop in town!
Main St, cutting edge of fashion and trends.
In Thornes Marketplace, Main Street, great place for fresh flowers.
Pleasant St off Main St, great selection of used CDs and vinyl records.  Also some VHS and DVDs.  You can listen before you buy.
Main St, upscale travel store.  Luggage, leather goods (wallets) bags and purses.  Also a good place to buy travel items like money belts and toiletry cases.
content=Amherst's store has recently moved to a spot in downtown Noho.  This location is bigger and more open, and as always, they have great prices for CDs and DVDs.

content=A division of the larger Provincetown store, home to all sorts of interesting merchandise for the "alternative lifestyle."  They have interesting clothes, jewelry, incense, and other paraphernalia.
content=Local division of the chain of stores, located in the old bank on Main Street.  Large selection of men's and women's apparel and home goods.

This little town is full of restaurants, you can pretty much find anything you crave.

value: content=Moroccan place, very tasty and inexpensive.
content=Vegetarian restaurant, wholesome and delicious. Try the Harvest Burger!.
content=This is where the locals go when they want to impress someone.
content=Many vegetarian and vegan options, plus delicious smoothies: try 9-1-1.
hours=Mo-Th, Su noon-10:30PM, Fr-Sa noon until midnight
content= Worth a special trip for the great ice cream. The servers will mix in ingredients called "smoosh-ins". Hot fudge sundaes and heavenly milkshakes available.
content=If you like Indian food, this is your place.
,  Breakfast-Brunch. Your typical diner (with diner coffee) but everything else is delicious. Try banana pancakes or waffles with strawberries and whipped cream.
content=Largest pizza in the world (or at least the Pioneer Valley.or Noho).
content=A pizza place run by the same people who own Spoletos, so you can expect not just your standard pepperoni, but also carmalized onions with white sauce or calimari pizza.
content=A fairly expensive restaurant but worth the prices. You won't be disappointed.

content=Named after, and located in the house of, Sylvester Graham, inventor of the Graham cracker. Very popular place, especially for breakfast. The house and surroundings are beautiful, but the food can be a little hit or miss.
content=Offers a mix of Chinese and Japanese cuisine, but serves surprisingly good sushi nonetheless.

content=Regularly voted the best sushi restaurant and the best japanese restaurant in the Pioneer Valley, Osaka has great service, innovative sushi ideas, and, best of all, GIANT boats to eat your sushi off.
, Main St, A mix of El Salvadorian, Mexican, and healthy foods.  Known for big burritos, great vegetarian options, and the barbecue chicken burrito.
content=Has menus for several Northampton restaurants on their website, including many of those listed above. As their name implies, they deliver orders from these restaurants.
, Main Street, This small but cozy Italian place has excellent fresh homemade pastas and other traditional Italian favorites with a Valley twist.  Try the sweet potato ravioli!
This cafe is technically in Florence, a section of Northampton.  Has great sandwiches, veggie-friendly, and soups.  Great quality food and atmosphere.

content=Unique "choose your own" style menu in which you pick a protein, a sauce, and two sides- large variety of options, and always a large list of special items- also offers appetizers, salads and panini.  Great atmosphere, live Jazz on Sunday nights, delicious food.  Call ahead if you want to get a seat!

content=Go to Zen when you're feeling Asian food, but can't make up your mind!  Zen's large menu of Pan-Asian Cuisine has quite the variety of options- many delicious Chinese, Japanese and Thai dishes.
content=Delicious Mediterranean food, a number of vegetarian options.  Try the stews, salads or crepes.  Dine inside (a bit crowded) or outside on the patio.

content=Interesting breakfast options, mainly scrambles and sandwiches (vegan options available).  Great sandwiches for lunch.  Small, but delicious menu, specials generally available.  Not really a quiet spot, but good food served quickly.

content=New vegetarian/vegan/raw food restaurant and smoothie bar.  Very unique menu- try the Noodle Dishes- "noodles" made out of zucchini and other vegetables with delicious sauce options.  Quite the variety of smoothies and juices available.
content=Authentic Tibetan cuisine, family owned, specializing in Yak dishes, but plenty of other options available for those not so daring!  Great, unique food!
content=Located right above Sierra Grille.  Delicious Italian food, nice atmosphere.
content=New frozen yogurt place on Main Street, serving all locally produced foods.  Pick a flavor of yogurt and load it up with fresh berries, candies, or whatever you like!
content=Mexican Restaurant owned by Spoletos serving traditional Mexican dishes, tapas, and the widest selection of Tequilas and Mescals in the region.  Try the flavored Margaritas or Mojitos!

content=A restaurant that embodies its name!  Local Burger offers a variety of specialized burgers, including turkey, veggie and portobello, in addition to beef.  Serves only fresh meats from local farms.
content=Large menu offering a wide variety of Thai specialties.
content=The Pioneer Valley's first brewpub, serving food this is as good as the beer is.
content=Lovely, quiet, unpretentious, the best coffee in the Valley (fresh every hour), yummy treats. Free NYT on the tables each morning.
content=Bar featuring 40 quality beers on tap.
content=A popular place to get good coffee and great baked goods while enjoying free WiFi.
content=A GBLT nightclub with various theme-driven nights:
(Goth, Industrial, Darkwave), Ages: 18+. The longest-running Goth/Industrial night in the area. (Goth/Alternative dress)
, 18+. The night starts out with Karaoke; and around 11PM, DJ Otis spins dance. There are drag shows on alternate weeks.
, 18+. 80's night - mostly new wave with some synthpop and goth/alternative thrown in. (80's/Goth/Alternative dress encouraged)
Located across from Pearl St Nightclub, underneath The Depot Restaurant.  Swanky, in a tunnel.  Leather armchairs and expensive, but tasty, martinis.
Only bar that allows 18+, but only on the first floor.  Serves food.  Second and third floors have pool and foosball.
content=Great little cafe in Florence serving coffee, specialty drinks, shakes, smoothies, breakfast and lunch!  Supports a number of local farms and other entities.
content=Just your typical Starbucks.  Not a ton of seating, but enough, considering the number of coffee shops in Noho.
content=In the center of town: by far, the nicest place to stay. The staff is always friendly and accommodating. The building itself is historic.
